text: What's up everybody? We're the Vagab
Brothers and this week we're talking the
top 10 things to do in Cancun and the
Riviera Maya.
Now, if you heard of Cancun, it's
probably from MTV Spring Break. Beaches,
booze, and bodies that make us feel like
we got to go to the gym more. Now, if
you're looking for that, you'll find it.
But trust us, there's plenty more to do
in the Riviera Maya. So, let's get into
it. Numero uno beaches. First and
foremost, Cancun is about sun and sand.
There are 30 miles of tropical white
sand beaches with beautiful blue water
that's going to make you want to dive
right in. Number two, nightife. Now, if
there's one thing Cancun is known for,
apart from the beaches, it's the
parties. It's definitely lots of fun,
but there's lots of cover charges and
it's full of foreigners. Number three,
Pel Carman. Another option is Padel
Carman. It's like the little sister to
Cancun. It used to be a sleepy port
town, but it's lately grown into a more
mellow alternative to the highrises of
Cancun. That's great if you're on a
budget. Number four, Tulum. Next, it's
time to get into the Maya culture.
Starting with the beachfront ruins of
Tulum. Now, from an archaeological
perspective, this late period Maya city
lacks the sublime architecture that the
Maya are famous for, but it's gorgeous
and you can even go swimming on the
beach. Number five, the ruins of Kopa.
By contrast, Kopa is a larger city than
Tulum and it's covered in jungle, kind
of like a Mayan version of anchor watt.
Best of all, you get to climb to the
tallest Mayan pyramid in Mexico. And
let's be honest, the selfie alone is
worth the trip.
Number six, Chichinita. Okay, so it's
not technically in the Riviera Maya.
It's 3 hours inland and in the Yucatan
province, but it's one of the seven new
wonders of the world, and it's one of
the best preserved ruins in Mexico.
Number seven, diving in cenotes. The
limestone sinkholes the Maya believed
were the portal to the underworld.
There's a thousand cenotees across the
Yukan Peninsula and their cool, clear
waters are the best way to beat the
heat, especially if you're scuba
certified because cenotes offer some of
the best cave diving in all the world.
Number eight, swimming with a whale
shark. If scuba diving in cenote seems a
little too claustrophobic,
why not go swimming in the middle of the
open ocean with a whale shark? Did you
hear me correctly? A freaking whale
shark. It's awesome experience, but make
sure you don't swim directly in front of
its mouth or you might get swallowed.
Number nine, Escadet. Now, we almost
never recommend touristic shows like
Escadet, but this one was really, really
well done. It tells the whole story of
Mexico from the Maya to the Spanish to
the Mexican Revolution. Plus, it
showcases all the different dances of
the regions of Mexico. Number 10, a
teame skull. Sweat out the week's
tequila in a teasal, a pre-Colombian
cleansing ritual held in a stone sweat
lodge guided by a shaman. Now, the ones
in the hotels are a little touristy, but
if you head to a Maya community like Las
Palmas, you can have an authentic
spiritual experience. So, those are our
top 10 tips for Cancun and the Rivera.
What are yours? If you're from Cancun or
you've been there, let us know your
recommendations in the comment box. And
if you haven't seen our vlog from Cancun
with Louis and Naen, make sure you check
it out in the info box. As always, if
you enjoyed the video, give it a thumbs
up, share it with your friends, and
click to subscribe. New videos every
Tuesday.
All right. later.
[Music]
Yo.
[Music]
